FeedItems.Title: NuGet.org will continue to support TLS 1.0 and 1.1 until further notice
FeedItems.Summary: Last November, we shared our two-stage plan for deprecating TLS 1.0/1.1 on NuGet.org and actions you can take today to ensure your systems use TLS 1.2. In that post, we announced that NuGet.org would...

FeedItems.Title: Deprecating TLS 1.0 and 1.1 on NuGet.org
FeedItems.Summary:
co-authored by Scott Bommarito
At Microsoft, using the latest and secure encryption techniques is very important to us to ensure the security and privacy of our customers. TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1,...

FeedItems.Title: Deprecating packages on nuget.org
FeedItems.Summary: We are excited to announce that nuget.org now supports package deprecation. This has been a long standing ask that will help the ecosystem use supported packages. As a package publisher on nuget.org,...

FeedItems.Title: New and improved NuGet Search is here!
FeedItems.Summary: It’s been a long time coming, and today we are excited to announce the new and improved search on NuGet.org leveraging Azure Search. We want to start this post with a huge thanks to you, the NuGet...

FeedItems.Title: Surfacing GitHub Usage for packages on NuGet.org
FeedItems.Summary: There are several criteria you can use today to evaluate NuGet packages. We received feedback that you would like even more information to help choose the right packages. We’re excited to...

FeedItems.Title: NuGet Spring 2019 Roadmap
FeedItems.Summary: We published our last NuGet roadmap in June last year. Many of the features announced were major additions to NuGet and we have been hard at work to implement those over the last few months. In this...

FeedItems.Title: Enable repeatable package restores using a lock file
FeedItems.Summary: With PackageReference, NuGet always tries to produce the same closure of package dependencies if the input package reference list has not changed. However, there are a few scenarios where it may not...

FeedItems.Title: Lock down your dependencies using configurable trust policies
FeedItems.Summary: For the past several months we have focused on various features to improve package security and trust. Around a year back, we had announced our plans on various signing functionalities that we have...

FeedItems.Title: Improved package debugging experience with the NuGet.org symbol server
FeedItems.Summary: Starting today, you can publish symbol packages to the NuGet.org symbol server. With NuGet.org as a single service provider for libraries and symbols, package authors and consumers will have a...

FeedItems.Title: Introducing Source Code Link for NuGet packages
FeedItems.Summary: NuGet.org now supports surfacing source code repository link for NuGet packages. This will enable package authors to surface both the project’s website and the source repository using the...

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Add support for alternate instrumentation system in browser " (#7971) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Progress on https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/3020

We will use this on nuget.org to swap out the instrumentation system with the Microsoft internal one that allows sending data to both Application Insights and to the internal endpoint which uses the "tenant key" configuration that I added.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Add support for alternate instrumentation system for browser " (#7971) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Progress on https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/3020

We will use this on nuget.org to swap out the instrumentation system with the Microsoft internal one that allows sending data to both Application Insights and to the internal endpoint which uses the "tenant key" configuration that I added.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Show Preview Window setting - minor refactor / redesign" (#9491) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Consider whether we should be using the Registry to persist the "Show preview window" setting in the PMUI.  This isn't an ideal use of the Registry.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/80558448-6cbc1d00-89a8-11ea-938b-446e0878aa6e.png)

Investigate whether we can move this setting to the VS Settings API ([current Setting logic](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.PackageManagement.UI/Xamls/PreviewWindow.xaml.cs#L89)).

A possible reason for using Registry may have been how our UI automated testing interacted with it, so that should be evaluated first to understand test changes that will be needed.

The design of this option being on 2 dialogs, and not kept in sync, was captured in this bug https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7901.

My suggestion is:
1. VS Setting persists the "default" value for previewing.
2. PMUI allows you to change that setting in a given Window. (eg, "I usually don't care, but this time I want to check the "preview" because I expect this package to make changes I'm worried about." ... or vice versa)
3. Registry is not involved at all.

//cc: @anangaur @chgill-MSFT

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Package Manager Settings Help Button (?) in VS2019 opens outdated VS2015 specific Docs" (#9490) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Visual Studio 2019 NuGet Settings dialog in `Tools ->NuGet Package Manager -> Package Manager Settings` has a Help Button (?) which opens the Docs page specific for vs2015. 

Selecting "?" in the top right....
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/80553601-72aa0200-8998-11ea-8551-7ffd94f4f7b8.png)

.....opens this [Docs Page](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/ide/adding-references-using-nuget-versus-an-extension-sdk?f1url=https%3A%2F%2Fmsdn.microsoft.com%2Fquery%2Fdev16.query%3FappId%3DDev16IDEF1%26l%3DEN-US%26k%3Dk(VS.ToolsOptionsPages.NuGet_Package_Manager.General)%26rd%3Dtrue&view=vs-2015) (with &view=vs-2015 in query string).

Note: I'm also not sure this is the best docs page as it's very generic info, and also even says it is specific to VS2015. Part of this work may be figuring out if we have a better doc to show and if not, addressing that (or in a separate docs issue).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/80553701-cddbf480-8998-11ea-9730-e3cb4e6636e7.png)

NuGet product used VSUI
NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 16.x

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "PMUI has XAML Binding Failures on Load" (#9489) at NuGet/Home

Launch PMUI (tested for Solution with Default Tab=Installed) and observe a number of XAML binding errors on load.
This is prior to selecting an item.

It's unknown whether these are causing tangible issues for users. I simply observed them while debugging.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "PMUI has XAML Binding Failures on Load" (#9488) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
1. Launch PMUI (tested for Solution with Default Tab=Installed), then Clear the Debug Output Window (to ignore errors from the Load).
2. Select a Package in the packages list of Installed tab.
3. Observe a number of XAML binding errors after selection.

It's unknown whether these are causing tangible issues for users. I simply observed them while debugging.

- System.Windows.Data   Error: 5 : Value produced by BindingExpression is not valid for target   property.; Value='<null>' BindingExpression:Path=Id;   DataItem='PackageSolutionDetailControlModel' (HashCode=3973482); target   element is 'TextBox' (Name='_packageId'); target property is 'Name' (type   'String')

- System.Windows.Data Error: 40 :   BindingExpression path error: 'InstalledVersion' property not found on   'object' ''PackageSolutionDetailControlModel' (HashCode=3973482)'.   BindingExpression:Path=InstalledVersion;   DataItem='PackageSolutionDetailControlModel' (HashCode=3973482); target   element is 'TextBlock' (Name='_InstalledVersion'); target property is   'Visibility' (type 'Visibility')

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Github doesn't parse SDK style projects for packages. Required nuspec" (#9057) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Haven't found a good way to report this to github yet but figured you might want to know and push on it. https://github.community/t5/How-to-use-Git-and-GitHub/Used-by-counter-not-showing-the-packages/m-p/39425#M9620

People using SDK Style projects aren't able to use some of githubs features for referencing packages because of this.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "HttpSourceAuthenticationHandler SemaphoreSlim future proofing" (#9463) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): Any, I think.

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): Any

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: Yes, it works, just an improvement in the logic.

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1.https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/1fbc87841107a627c6f4349f733e48c28fcff028/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Protocol/HttpSource/HttpSourceAuthenticationHandler.cs#L22
2.  In case `WaitAsync` throws, `Release` should not be called. Although, `WaitAsync` only is documented to throw `ObjectDisposedException`, which would cause `Release` to throw `ObjectDisposeException` later on, this would make the code resilient to changes to other overloads, which can throw other exceptions too, like `OperationCanceledException` if a cancellation token is passed.

PR open already: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/3357

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Nuspec filtering takes a very long time for packages with many files in them" (#9451) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Please read the following information before posting the issue.

## Details about Problem

Nuget.exe, pack task, etc.

5.4.0+ tested

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Generate a nuspec file with a large-ish number of files (the one in question had about 800). E.g.:

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<package xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/packaging/2011/10/nuspec.xsd">
  <metadata>
    <id>testSdkPublish</id>
    <version>5.0.100-dev</version>
    <authors>Microsoft</authors>
    <owners>Microsoft</owners>
    <requireLicenseAcceptance>true</requireLicenseAcceptance>
    <license type="expression">MIT</license>
    <licenseUrl>https://licenses.nuget.org/MIT</licenseUrl>
    <icon>Icon.png</icon>
    <projectUrl>https://github.com/mmitche/sdk</projectUrl>
    <description>Package Description</description>
    <copyright>© Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.</copyright>
    <packageTypes>
      <packageType name="DotnetTool" />
    </packageTypes>
    <repository type="git" url="https://github.com/mmitche/sdk" commit="9accfd73af94b7309af26e71074a04bce22bb30d" />
  </metadata>
  <files>
    <file src="C:\r\sdk\artifacts\bin\Tests\Microsoft.NET.Publish.Tests\Debug\publish\Microsoft.NET.Publish.Tests.deps.json" target="tools\netcoreapp5.0\any\Microsoft.NET.Publish.Tests.deps.json" />
    <file src="C:\r\sdk\artifacts\obj\Tests\Microsoft.NET.Publish.Tests\DotnetToolSettings.xml" target="tools\netcoreapp5.0\any\DotnetToolSettings.xml" />
    <file src="C:\r\sdk\artifacts\bin\Tests\Microsoft.NET.Publish.Tests\Debug\publish\xunit.runner.visualstudio.dotnetcore.testadapter.dll" target="tools\netcoreapp5.0\any\xunit.runner.visualstudio.dotnetcore.testadapter.dll" />
...
```

2. Pack with nuget.exe pack
3. The pack will take an excessive amount of time.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Test Failure][Unstable]The info in the “Preview Changes” window is not correct when trying to uinstall an embedded icon package from the exist solution" (#9487) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev\5.7.0.6595
VS Version: Master\30027.154
OS: Windows-10-Enterprise-RS5
## Detailed repro steps 
1. Opne an exist solution that already installed several embedded icon packages.
2. Open the solution PM UI and go to “Installed” tab.
3. Choose an embedded icon package and click “Uninstall” button.
## Expected
The info in the prompt “Preview Changes” window should be correct.
## Actual
The info in the prompt “Preview Changes” window is not correct as below screenshot. It try to install a package which had been installed on the project.
![PreviewChanges](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/80495022-f2849c00-8999-11ea-8963-5db521bb2a0b.png)
## Notes
1. It also repro in the project PM UI.
2. Package “FwPackage” is a local created .NET Framework 4.8 package with embedded icon. Package “classlib.net48” is installed from devops source: https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/farhub/_packaging/farhub/nuget/v3/index.json.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Deprecating TLS 1.0 and 1.1 on NuGet.org – Stage 1" (#42) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
## NuGet.org will temporarily remove support for TLS 1.0/1.1 on February 26, 2020

We plan to temporarily remove support for TLS 1.0/1.1 across 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each, to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. If you discover that you are impacted and cannot identify a workaround, please open an issue on the NuGet Gallery GitHub repo.

Read this blog post to learn more and to identify the test slot time in your time zone - https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/deprecating-tls-1-0-and-1-1-on-nuget-org-stage-1/
